courseTitle: Introduction to Microscopy and Bacterial Shapes

pageData.titleName2: Introduction to Microscopy and Bacterial Shapes

pageData.text: Microscopes allow scientists to observe cells and other details that are not visible to the naked eye. In this investigation, you will learn about the parts of a microscope, stage movement, how to calculate total magnification of the microscope, basic care and handling of a microscope, and the importance of <button class='glossary-text'>resolution</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>depth of field</button>. During the investigation you will look at prepared <button class='glossary-text'>slides</button> of the letter “e,” colored threads, cork, dust, a tick, and a mite. While viewing these slides, you will learn how to position and move slides on a microscope stage, focus on an object on a microscope slide, and handle and care for a microscope and microscope slides.

You will also learn the first step in identifying <button class='glossary-text'>bacteria</button>, which is categorizing the cells by shape. The three most common bacterial cell shapes are <button class='glossary-text'>bacillus</button> (rod-shaped), <button class='glossary-text'>coccus</button> (spherical), and spiral. You will use a microscope to view a representative smear of each cell type.

pageData.text:
The microscope has allowed for many advancements in science. are very small and because they are so small, they have a high surface area to volume ratio. This allows them to readily take up as many nutrients as possible. It is widely believed that bacteria are so small that they can only be seen with the aid of a microscope. However, some bacteria are large enough to be seen with the naked eye. In 1999, Heide Schulz was examining sediment cores from the ocean. The cores came from 300 feet below the waters near the Namibia's Skeleton Coast. In the samples, she noticed “pearl”-like organisms1. When she looked at these structures under a microscope, she discovered that they were not pearls, but rather giant bacteria. The researchers named the new microbe the "Sulfur pearl of Namibia," Thiomargarita namibiensis. The cells are three-quarters of a millimeter in diameter, and they use sulfide and nitrate as their nutrient source. The sediment in the ocean is low in nutrients and only when occasional storms occur are nutrients stirred up and replenished. About 98% of T. namibiensis is a very large vacuole that it uses to store nitrogen so it can survive until the next storm comes.1Wuethrich, B. (1999). Giant sulfur-eating microbe found. Science.
https://www.science.org/content/article/giant-sulfur-eating-microbe-found

pageData.subTitle: Microscopy
pageData.text: Scientists use microscopes to observe objects that are too small to be seen (or too small to be seen in detail) with the unaided eye. Microscopes have played a pivotal role in our understanding of plant and animal cells, crystals, and microorganisms. Two common types of microscopes are <button class='glossary-text'>stereomicroscopes</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>compound light microscopes</button>. Both types manipulate light to create an enlarged image of an object.

Stereomicroscopes typically are used to view relatively large objects, such as fruit flies. They usually have a large —the space between the lens and the specimen—which makes them ideal for use in dissections. For this reason, stereomicroscopes are often referred to as dissecting microscopes.

Compound microscopes are used to view even smaller objects. Objects viewed under a compound microscope are typically mounted on a microscope <button class='glossary-text'>slide</button>, a small, rectangular piece of glass, which is covered with a thin, protective piece of glass called a <button class='glossary-text'>coverslip</button>. A compound microscope has a much smaller working distance than a stereomicroscope.

Specimens intended for viewing with a compound light microscope are usually thin, and may also be chemically cleared. This allows light to pass through the specimen with a minimum amount of light scattering. The scattering of light rays results in a loss of <button class='glossary-text'>resolution</button> (the ability to distinguish between two adjacent objects). The lower the resolution of an image, the blurrier it appears.

Specimens are often stained with one or more dyes during the preparation of a microscope slide. Most specimens, especially after they have been preserved and processed into thin sections, have little, if any, color. This results in very little contrast when the specimen is viewed. Dyes add contrast for greater ease of viewing.

When a suitably-prepared specimen is viewed with a properly-adjusted microscope, the resulting image will not only be magnified, it will also have high resolution and good contrast. Thus, the microscope will reveal fine details that could not be detected by the unaided eye.

pageData.text: Every microscope possesses at least one <button class='glossary-text'>eyepiece</button>, or ocular lens. Those with only a single eyepiece are known as <button class='glossary-text'>monocular</button> microscopes. Many compound microscopes are <button class='glossary-text'>binocular</button> microscopes and have two eyepieces, which you look through with both eyes as you would with a pair of binoculars. The long cylinder extending from the eyepiece is called the <button class='glossary-text'>body tube</button>, or monocular tube. If there are two eyepieces and tubes, these are called binocular tubes. At the opposite end of the tube(s) are a series of magnifying <button class='glossary-text'>objectives</button>. Each objective magnifies objects to a different power. The lowest power is usually 4x, and is referred to as the <button class='glossary-text'>scanning objective</button>. The highest power is usually either 40x or 100x.

The 100x lens is an oil immersion objective and will not be required for this investigation. The 40x lens is called the high power (or “high-dry”) objective. There is usually a single objective between the scanning and , most commonly with a magnification of 10x. It is known as the . The objective used to view an object can be changed by rotating the revolving located near the bottom of the tube above the stage. Most modern microscopes are , which means that if the image is focused, it should remain in focus when you change the objective with minimal fine-tuning using the fine adjustment knob.

pageData.subTitle: Depth of Field
pageData.text: It is important to remember that the objects observed under a microscope are three-dimensional. An object may appear flat, especially after being pressed under a cover-slip. However, when magnified, the depth of the material on the becomes more apparent. When you view an object and only part of it is in focus, you are observing the limits of the microscope’s , which refers to the thickness (or depth) of an area under the microscope that can be viewed in focus. Depth of field is shallower on higher power than on lower power. In other words, when you view an object under higher power, less of it is in focus at one time than when the same object is viewed under lower power. offer a greater depth of field than compound microscopes because they are used at lower magnifications.

pageData.subTitle: Calculating Magnification
pageData.text: An object is magnified by both the <button class='glossary-text'>eyepiece</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>objective</button> lens of the microscope. To determine the total magnification, multiply the magnification power of the eyepiece (which is printed near the lens) by the magnification power of the objective lens being used to view the object.
Total Magnification = (eyepiece lens power) × (objective lens power)
For example, if human cheek cells are being viewed using the 40x objective lens with a microscope that has a 10x ocular lens, the total magnification of the cheek cells is 40 x 10 = 400x.

Greater magnification does not always produce better viewing. A clear, sharp 200x image is more useful than a blurry 600x image. As magnification increases, the amount of light entering the lens decreases. Therefore, objects viewed at higher power will appear darker and may not be as clear. By adjusting the <button class='glossary-text'>iris diaphragm</button>, you can increase or decrease the amount of light directed onto the <button class='glossary-text'>slide</button>.

pageData.subTitle: Basic Care and Handling of a Microscope and Microscope Slides
pageData.text:
Microscopes are expensive, delicate pieces of equipment. Follow the guidelines below to keep your microscope in the best possible condition.
  • Never touch the lenses of the microscope with your fingers.
  • Use only lens paper to clean the lenses since fibers in paper towels or toilet paper can scratch the glass.
  • When storing a microscope, rotate the so that it is on the lowest power objective.
  • Adjust the stage so that it is as close to the objective as possible.
  • Keep the microscope covered when not in use to keep dust away.
  • Transport a microscope by using one hand to hold the scope by the arm and the other hand to support the base.
  • Store microscope slides out of direct light to prevent stained specimens from fading.

pageData.subTitle: Bacterial Shapes
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Bacteria</button> are prokaryotic organisms, meaning that each is a single cell that lacks a nucleus or other membranous organelles. Bacteria are perhaps best known as <button class='glossary-text'>pathogens</button>: microorganisms that cause infectious diseases such as strep throat, gonorrhea, and Lyme disease. However, only a fraction of bacterial species cause infections in humans. Most do not adversely affect us, and in fact, many are beneficial.

Whether trying to diagnose a potential bacterial infection or monitor bacterial cultures used in food production, it is vital to be able to identify the species that are present. There are numerous tests available to help identify bacteria, but the first step is often microscopic examination. One of the first clues in trying to identify unknown bacteria is cell shape. The three most common bacterial cell shapes are , , and spiral. Oftentimes, the characteristic cell shape of a bacterial species appears in its scientific name. For example, Lactobacillus acidophilus, discussed below, has a characteristic bacillus shape. (The rest of the name refers to the “acid-loving” nature of the bacterium, which grows best at a lower pH, as well as its ability to produce lactic acid by fermentation.)

A bacillus is a rod-shaped cell. Multiples are called . They usually occur either singly (Figure 2) or in chains of cells that adhere to one another (), depending on the species. Many bacilli can move about their environment with the use of long, slender appendages called , as seen in Figure 2.

Lactobacillus acidophilus is an example of a beneficial bacillus species. This natural inhabitant of the human gastrointestinal tract and vagina helps to protect against the overgrowth or invasion of potentially harmful microbes. Escherichia coli also inhabits the lower portion of the human gastrointestinal tract and is generally beneficial, although there are strains that can cause food poisoning. Other harmful bacilli include: Bacillus anthracis, which causes anthrax; Clostridium tetanii, which causes tetanus; and certain members of the genus Salmonella, which cause a type of foodborne illness known as salmonellosis.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Microscopic image of several bacilli that occur singly
Figure 3: Microscopic image of four bacilli that occur in a chain of cells that adhere to one another

pageData.text: A is a spherical cell. Multiples are called . They may occur singly, but more commonly adhere to one another in pairs, chains, or even clusters (Figure 4), of varying size depending on the species. Most cocci species lack . Strep throat is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, and Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of infections of the skin, gastrointestinal tract, and respiratory tract. One strain, known as MRSA (short for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) is of great concern because of its resistance to treatment with the antibiotic methicillin as well as similar drugs. Gonorrhea, a sexually transmitted bacterial infection, is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Streptococcus thermophilus is often used (along with certain members of the Lactobacillus genus) to convert milk into yogurt.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Microscopic image of cocci that have adhered to one another in many clusters of varying size

pageData.text: There are two types of spiral <button class='glossary-text'>bacteria</button>. Both occur singly, not adhering to one another, and are shaped like springs or coils. It is easiest to distinguish between them when they are living due to the way the cells move.

A (plural, ), like the example in , is relatively large for a bacterium, and rigid. If it is able to move, it does so with the use of flagella that extend from both ends of the spiral. Spirillum volutans is a natural inhabitant of stagnant freshwater, and does not cause disease in humans. It is known for being one of the largest bacterial species: a single cell may be 60 µm long.

A (plural, spirochetes) is more flexible than a , and moves with a distinctive twisting motion due to the internal location of its . Treponema pallidium is the causative agent of the sexually-transmitted infection syphilis. Borrelia burgdorferi causes Lyme disease, a tick-borne infection. Figure 6 depicts Borrelia spirochetes in a blood sample. The larger, round, red objects are red blood cells.

In this investigation, you will use a microscope to examine an example of each of the three common bacterial shapes. The bacterial cells have been applied to the surface of the in three separate, roughly circular “smears.” They were then fixed, a step that simultaneously kills and preserves the cells, while making them adhere to the slide, and then stained with dye to make them easier to see. One smear on the slide contains , and another contains ; to represent spiral-shaped , there is a third smear consisting of .

Note: All three smears have been stained with the same dye, which enables the identification of cell shape. It will not be possible to clearly view cell appendages such as flagella; these are only made visible with special staining and/or microscopy techniques.Please be aware that bacterial cells may naturally adhere to one another. Also, most smears are not completely uniform. There are often thick clumps of cells in one or more areas of the smear. Plan to view each smear carefully to distinguish individual cells.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for Activities 1-2 of this investigation. Before starting any activities, learn the parts and functions of a microscope. In Activity 1, you will turn on the microscope, adjust the stage, and place a slide on the stage. Next, you will focus the slide using the coarse and fine adjustments, and adjust the strength of the light source. Finally, you will observe the slide at higher magnifications. In Activity 2, you will replace slides on the stage and bring the slide into focus. Next, you will observe the slide at higher magnifications, and sketch or photograph your observations. Then, you will calculate the total magnification at which the slide was observed. You will repeat this activity until 5 total slides have been observed.

If you choose to use oil immersion, remember to apply the minimum amount of oil needed to the area of the slide under study. Use just enough to fill the space between the oil immersion objective lens and the surface of the slide. Use immersion oil only with the oil immersion objective. As soon as you are finished, gently clean the objective and the slide with lens paper and lens cleaning solution. Do not press down on the slide during cleaning, as this may displace the .
In Activity 1, you will learn how to use a microscope by experimenting with and adjusting all of the components of the microscope. You will use this understanding in Activity 2.

typeBefore.text: Note: If your microscope has an oil immersion (100x ) , identify it, but do not use it during Activities 1 and 2.

pageData.text:
When you are ready to view a microscope , illuminate the microscope by doing one of the following:
  1. If your microscope has a light, turn on the power so that the light at the base of the microscope is illuminated.
  2. If your microscope has a mirror instead of a light, adjust the mirror so that it reflects light from the room through the condenser lenses.
Caution: If your microscope has a mirror, do not reflect sunlight off the mirror. This can damage your eyes.
Lower the stage as far away from the objectives as possible.
Turn the <button class='glossary-text'>nosepiece</button> to the scanning (lowest power) objective.
For this activity, you may select any slide in the Introduction to Microscopy slide set. Hold the microscope slide so that the slide label is on the left.
Place the slide, with the label to the left, onto the microscope stage.
Secure the slide on the stage with the stage clips.

Center the slide on the stage so that the object to view is directly under the objective and light is shining through it. If your microscope has stage adjustment knobs, rotate them to move the slide side to side or back and forth as needed to bring the object into view through the <button class='glossary-text'>eyepiece</button>.
Look at the stage from eye level and use the coarse adjustment knob to bring the slide close to the objective without actually touching it.
While looking through the eyepiece(s), use the coarse adjustment knob to bring the object roughly into focus. Then use the fine adjustment knob to bring the object into sharp focus.

Note: If you wear corrective lenses, you may find it easier to focus the microscope without your glasses or contacts. If you struggle to focus the scope while wearing corrective lenses, try again without the lenses.
To adjust the amount of light shining on the object, use the <button class='glossary-text'>iris diaphragm</button> control beneath the stage.

With the object in focus and centered, switch the microscope to the next higher objective, the . Then, use the fine adjustment knob to bring the object into focus. Do not use the coarse adjustment knob with higher power objectives.
When you are finished viewing the slide, turn back to the <button class='glossary-text'>scanning objective</button> and lower the stage completely. Then carefully remove the microscope slide.
Repeat this procedure to view all of the slides in Activity 2.

In Activity 2, you will examine the prepared <button class='glossary-text'>slides</button> of the letter e, colored threads, cork, household dust, and a mite and a tick using the microscope. You will sketch or photograph the specimens and record the total magnification of each image.

The letter “e” is good for the first viewing experience because it allows you to practice focusing and positioning slides. Moreover, you will observe several optical effects produced by the microscope. A microscope’s is the area of the circle that is visible when looking through the ocular lens. The diameter of the field decreases with an increase in magnification.
  1. Before placing it on the stage, look at the letter “e” slide. Note the size and orientation of the “e” on the slide.
Note: Remember, the label should be on the left.
1. View the letter “e” using the as described in Activity 1.
Draw or take a picture of the letter “e” as it appears through the . Calculate and record the total magnification in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text:
1. Move the slide to the left on the stage. Note the direction in which the “e” appears to move in Data Table 1.
  2. Move the slide to the right on the stage. Note the direction in which the “e” appears to move in Data Table 1.
  3. Move the slide forward on the stage, and then backward. Note the direction in which the “e” appears to be moving in Data Table 1.
  4. Advance to the . Can you see all of the letter “e?” Note your observation in Data Table 1.

Viewing the colored threads will help you understand the relationship between focus and , which is the distance above and below an object that is in focus. It varies with different and magnifications.
  1. Pick up this slide and inspect the crossed threads.
  2. View the slide under scanning power, and locate the area where the three threads intersect.
  3. Switch to the low power objective. Adjust the focus as needed.
Draw or take a picture of the intersection of the threads. Calculate and record the total magnification in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text:
1. Use the fine adjustment knob to focus on the yellow thread instead of the intersection of the threads.
  2. Without adjusting the focus, move the stage so that you are now looking at the red thread.
  3. Adjust the focus to bring the red thread into focus.
  4. Without adjusting the focus, look again at the edges of the yellow thread and determine whether it is still in focus. Note your observations in Data Table 1.

Cork is derived from the bark (outer) tissue of the cork oak. In 1665, Robert Hooke first coined the word “cell” as he described the structure of the walls of a thin piece of cork. The walls reminded him of the walls of a honeycomb.
  1. Observe the cross-section of cork under scanning power.
  2. Adjust the focus to examine different layers of the cork. If necessary, adjust the diaphragm to get a more detailed look at the cork cells.
  3. Switch to the low power objective and observe the cork. Adjust the focus to see the various layers.
  4. Switch to the high power (high-dry) objective. Adjust the focus as needed.
Draw or take a picture of the cork. Calculate and record the total magnification in Data Table 1 along with notes on your observations of this specimen.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text:
Household dust may look boring to the naked eye, but it can prove to be quite interesting when viewed under a microscope. Sometimes forensic experts use dust as evidence in criminal investigations.
  1. Observe the dust under scanning power. Focus on the larger objects that can be observed under scanning power.
  2. Switch to low power and observe the smaller objects.
Draw or take a picture of the dust. Calculate and record the total magnification in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: 1. Can you identify any of the particles on the slide? Do you see fibers from clothing or rugs? Do you see particles such as human hair, pet hair, or soil? Note your observations in Data Table 1.

Tick and Mite
  1. Place the tick and mite slide onto the microscope and focus on the tick under scanning power.
Note: The tick is the larger of the two organisms on the slide.
Draw or take a picture of the tick. Record the picture and magnification in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text:
1. Advance to the low power objective, then the high power (high-dry) objective. How much of the field of view is occupied by the tick at each magnification? Note this observation in Data Table 1.
  2. Locate the mite on the slide. Focus on the mite under scanning power.
  3. Increase the magnification on the mite from scanning power to low power.
Draw or take a picture of the mite. Calculate and record the total magnification in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: 1. Advance to the high power (high-dry) objective. How much of the field of view is occupied by the mite at each magnification? Note this observation in Data Table 1.

In Activity 3, you will observe a <button class='glossary-text'>slide</button> with 3 smears, each with a differently shaped bacterial species. You will practice identifying and comparing the different bacterial shapes.

Examine the <button class='glossary-text'>bacteria</button> <button class='glossary-text'>slide</button> with the unaided eye. Placing the slide on a piece of blank white paper may be helpful. This will help you determine the locations of the three bacterial smears you will be observing.
Place the slide on the stage of your microscope. Move the slide so that the smear nearest the label is illuminated.

Look through the <button class='glossary-text'>scanning objective</button>, and focus so you can see the bacterial smear. Little detail will be visible, but you should be able to see the stain associated with the cells.

Switch to the <button class='glossary-text'>low power objective</button>, and adjust the focus as necessary. With most microscopes, you will be able to see individual bacterial cells, although they will probably look like tiny spots.

Switch to the high power (high-dry) <button class='glossary-text'>objective</button>. Adjust the focus as necessary; you should be able to distinguish the shapes of individual bacterial cells. Make a tentative note of which bacterial shape is represented in the first smear. You do not need make a final decision on the shape until you have viewed all three smears.

Note: If your microscope has an oil immersion objective, you may opt to use it to obtain greater magnification. However, you should do so only after obtaining sharp, clear focus with the . It is extremely difficult to focus on objects as small as most under oil immersion unless precise focus was first obtained with the high power objective.

Without changing objectives, carefully move the slide until you have reached the second (middle) smear. Look through the <button class='glossary-text'>eyepiece</button>(s) while you move the slide, so you can tell when you have reached the next smear. You may need to adjust the focus very slightly to view the cells. As before, scan throughout the smear to find the best area for discerning individual cells, and note your initial impression of the cell shape represented.

Note: If you are unable to focus on the next smear, it may be necessary to go back to using the scanning objective and repeat the entire focusing process. If you are using an oil immersion objective, be careful not to get oil on any of the other objectives, as they may be permanently damaged.

Without changing objectives, carefully move the slide until you have reached the third smear. Look through the eyepiece(s) while you move the slide and adjust the focus very slightly if necessary. As with the first two smears, scan throughout the smear to find cells that can be distinguished individually, and note your initial impression of the cell shape represented.

Without changing objectives, observe each smear again until you feel confident identifying the three different cell shapes. The <button class='glossary-text'>bacilli</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>spirilla</button> can be particularly challenging to differentiate, depending on the <button class='glossary-text'>resolution</button> capability of the lens system in your microscope. For this reason, you may want to make a final comparison between just the two smears that you have identified as containing either bacilli or spirilla.

To document your work, take or draw a picture of several cells from each smear, and complete Data Table 2. The highest magnification used for viewing the smears should be used for this step. Calculate the total magnification used to obtain the images using the formula below, and enter it in Data Table 2.Total Magnification = (eyepiece lens power) × (objective lens power)
pageData.altText: camera symbol

text: If the oil immersion <button class='glossary-text'>objective</button> was used, thoroughly clean the objective and the <button class='glossary-text'>slide</button>, using lens paper and lens cleaning solution.
Return the microscope slides to their storage boxes and place them with the kit.
Cover the microscope and store it for future use.

A map describing the procedural workflow for Activities 1-2 of this investigation. Before starting any activities, learn the parts and functions of a microscope. In Activity 1, you will turn on the microscope, adjust the stage, and place a slide on the stage. Next, you will focus the slide using the coarse and fine adjustments, and adjust the strength of the light source. Finally, you will observe the slide at higher magnifications. In Activity 2, you will replace slides on the stage and bring the slide into focus. Next, you will observe the slide at higher magnifications, and sketch or photograph your observations. Then, you will calculate the total magnification at which the slide was observed. You will repeat this activity until 5 total slides have been observed.

A map describing the procedural workflow for Activity 3 of this investigation. After Activity 2, you will place a slide on the stage and observe the smear. Then, bring the smear into focus and observe it at different magnifications. Next, identify the shape of the bacteria. When you have observed 3 smears, compare the shape of the bacteria between smears. Finally, draw or photograph the smears and calculate the total magnification for your image.

data.title: Bacilli/bacillus
data.content: Rod-shaped bacteria

data.title: Bacteria
data.content: Prokaryotic organisms that are often pathogens; singular, bacterium

data.title: Binocular
data.content: Describes a microscope with two eyepieces

data.title: Body tube
data.content: The long cylinder extending from the eyepiece

data.title: Cocci/coccus
data.content: Spherical bacteria

data.title: Compound light microscope
data.content: A type of microscope that uses two sets of lenses (a compound lens system) to obtain higher magnification than a stereomicroscope

data.title: Coverslip
data.content: A thin, protective piece of glass

data.title: Depth of field
data.content: The thickness (or depth) of an area under the microscope that can be viewed in focus

data.title: Eyepiece
data.content: The part of a microscope through which the user views a specimen or slide; it contains an ocular lens

data.title: Field of view
data.content: The the maximum area visible when looking through the ocular lens

data.title: Flagella
data.content: Long thin appendages that extend beyond the cell wall and propel the cell along; singular, flagellum

data.title: High power objective
data.content: The high power lens, usually either 40x or 100x; also called the high-dry objective

data.title: (Iris) diaphragm
data.content: Regulates the amount of light directed onto the slide

data.title: Low power objective
data.content: The lens between the scanning and high power objectives, most commonly a magnification of 10x

data.title: Monocular
data.content: Describes a microscope with one eyepiece

data.title: Nosepiece
data.content: Holds the objective lenses

data.title: Objective
data.content: A magnifying lens found at the opposite end of the of the body tube

data.title: Parfocal
data.content: The ability of a microscope to remain in focus when there is a change to the objective with minimal fine-tuning if the image is already in focus

data.title: Pathogen
data.content: A microbe that causes disease

data.title: Resolution
data.content: The ability of a microscope to distinguish between two adjacent objects

data.title: Scanning objective
data.content: The lowest power objective, usually 4×

data.title: Slide
data.content: A small, rectangular piece of glass

data.title: Spirilla/spirillum
data.content: Rigid, spiral-shaped bacteria

data.title: Spirochete(s)
data.content: Flexible, spiral-shaped bacteria

data.title: Stereomicroscope
data.content: A type of microscope with a large working distance; also called a dissecting microscope

data.title: Working distance
data.content: The space between the lens and the specimen
